course.title: SVG Tutorial
course.description: Learn Scalable Vector Graphics step by step

sections.heading: Learn SVG
paragraphs: SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics.
SVG defines vector-based graphics in XML format.
SVG graphics are scalable and do not lose quality when zoomed or resized.
SVG is supported by all major browsers.

sections.heading: SVG Example
paragraphs: Below is a simple example of an SVG graphic.
sections.code: My first SVG

sections.heading: What You Should Already Know
paragraphs: Before learning SVG, you should understand:
HTML
Basic XML

sections.heading: What is SVG?
paragraphs: SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics.
SVG is used to define vector-based graphics for the Web.
SVG graphics are written in XML.
Each SVG element and attribute can be animated.
SVG is a W3C recommendation.
SVG works with CSS, DOM, XSL, and JavaScript.

sections.heading: SVG Versions
paragraphs: SVG 1.0 became a W3C Recommendation in 2001.
SVG 1.1 became a Recommendation in 2003.
SVG 1.1 Second Edition became a Recommendation in 2011.

sections.heading: Advantages of SVG
paragraphs: SVG images can be created and edited using any text editor.
SVG images are scalable and do not lose quality.
SVG images are searchable, indexable, and scriptable.
SVG graphics are resolution-independent.
SVG is an open standard.
SVG files are pure XML.

sections.heading: How SVG Works
paragraphs: SVG uses elements and attributes to draw shapes.
It supports shapes like rectangles, circles, ellipses, lines, and polygons.
SVG also supports animations, filters, gradients, and JavaScript interaction.

sections.heading: Creating SVG Images
paragraphs: SVG images can be created using any text editor.
They can also be created using graphic tools like Inkscape.
This tutorial focuses on writing SVG code manually.

sections.heading: SVG in HTML
paragraphs: SVG elements can be embedded directly inside HTML pages.
SVG graphics are written in XML and displayed directly in the browser.

sections.heading: Embedding SVG in HTML
paragraphs: You can embed SVG directly into HTML using the <svg> tag.
SVG elements work like normal HTML elements.

sections.heading: Basic SVG Example
paragraphs: Below is an example of an SVG embedded inside an HTML document.
sections.code: My first SVG

sections.heading: SVG Code Explanation
paragraphs: The <svg> element defines the SVG container.
The width and height attributes define the size of the SVG.
The xmlns attribute defines the SVG namespace.
The <circle> element draws a circle.
cx and cy define the center of the circle.
r defines the radius of the circle.
stroke and stroke-width define the border.
fill defines the inside color.

sections.heading: Important SVG Rules
paragraphs: SVG elements must always be closed.
SVG is case-sensitive.
All attribute values must be written inside quotes.
Lowercase element names are recommended.

sections.heading: Another SVG Example
paragraphs: This example shows multiple SVG elements inside one graphic.
sections.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>

<svg width="150" height="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="green" />
  <circle cx="75" cy="50" r="40" fill="yellow" />
  <text x="75" y="60" font-size="30" text-anchor="middle" fill="red">SVG</text>
</svg>

</body>
</html>

sections.heading: SVG Element Explanation
paragraphs: <rect> draws a rectangle.
<circle> draws a circle.
<text> displays text inside the SVG.
x and y define text position.
text-anchor controls text alignment.

sections.heading: SVG Shapes
paragraphs: SVG provides several predefined shape elements.
These include rectangle, circle, ellipse, line, polyline, polygon, and path.

sections.heading: SVG Rectangle (<rect>)
paragraphs: The <rect> element is used to create rectangles.
It can also be used to create rounded rectangles.

sections.heading: Basic Rectangle Example
paragraphs: This example creates a rectangle with width, height and color.
sections.code:
<svg width="300" height="130" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <rect width="200" height="100" x="10" y="10" rx="20" ry="20" fill="blue" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Rectangle with Border
paragraphs: This example adds a stroke (border) to the rectangle.
sections.code:
<svg width="320" height="130" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <rect width="300" height="100" x="10" y="10"
    style="fill:rgb(0,0,255); stroke-width:3; stroke:red" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Rectangle with Opacity
paragraphs: The fill-opacity and stroke-opacity properties control transparency.
sections.code:
<svg width="300" height="170" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <rect width="150" height="150" x="10" y="10"
    style="fill:blue; stroke:pink; stroke-width:5; fill-opacity:0.1; stroke-opacity:0.9" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Rectangle with Overall Opacity
paragraphs: The opacity property affects the entire element.
sections.code:
<svg width="300" height="170" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <rect width="150" height="150" x="10" y="10"
    style="fill:blue; stroke:pink; stroke-width:5; opacity:0.5" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Rounded Rectangle
paragraphs: Rounded corners can be created using rx and ry attributes.
sections.code:
<svg width="300" height="170" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <rect width="150" height="150" x="10" y="10" rx="20" ry="20"
    style="fill:red; stroke:black; stroke-width:5; opacity:0.5" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Circle
paragraphs: The <circle> element is used to create circles in SVG.
It is one of the basic SVG shape elements.

sections.heading: Basic Circle Example
paragraphs: This example creates a simple circle using SVG.
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <circle r="45" cx="50" cy="50" fill="red" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Circle Code Explanation
paragraphs: The r attribute defines the radius of the circle.
The cx and cy attributes define the center position.
The fill attribute defines the color of the circle.

sections.heading: Circle with Border
paragraphs: This example adds a border around the circle.
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <circle r="45" cx="50" cy="50" fill="red" stroke="green" stroke-width="3" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Border Explanation
paragraphs: The stroke attribute defines the border color.
The stroke-width attribute defines the border thickness.

sections.heading: Circle with Opacity
paragraphs: The opacity attribute controls the transparency of the circle.
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <circle r="45" cx="50" cy="50" fill="red" stroke="green" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.5" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Opacity Explanation
paragraphs: Opacity values range from 0 to 1.
Lower values make the shape more transparent.

sections.heading: SVG Ellipse
paragraphs: The <ellipse> element is used to create an ellipse.
An ellipse is similar to a circle, but it has different x and y radii.

rows: Required. X-axis radius of the ellipse
Required. Y-axis radius of the ellipse

sections.heading: Basic Ellipse Example
paragraphs: This example creates a simple ellipse using SVG.
sections.code:
<svg height="140" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <ellipse rx="100" ry="50" cx="120" cy="80"
    style="fill:yellow; stroke:green; stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Ellipse Code Explanation
paragraphs: The rx attribute defines the horizontal radius.
The ry attribute defines the vertical radius.
The cx and cy attributes define the center position of the ellipse.

sections.heading: Multiple Ellipses
paragraphs: Multiple ellipses can be layered to create visual effects.
sections.code:
<svg height="150" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <ellipse cx="240" cy="100" rx="220" ry="30" fill="purple" />
  <ellipse cx="220" cy="70" rx="190" ry="20" fill="lime" />
  <ellipse cx="210" cy="45" rx="170" ry="15" fill="yellow" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Two Ellipses Example
paragraphs: This example shows two overlapping ellipses.
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <ellipse cx="240" cy="50" rx="220" ry="30" fill="yellow" />
  <ellipse cx="220" cy="50" rx="190" ry="20" fill="white" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Line
paragraphs: The <line> element is used to create straight lines in SVG.
A line is drawn between two points defined by x and y coordinates.

sections.heading: Basic Line Example
paragraphs: This example creates a line from (0,0) to (300,200).
sections.code:
<svg height="200" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <line x1="0" y1="0" x2="300" y2="200" style="stroke:red; stroke-width:2" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Line Code Explanation
paragraphs: x1 and y1 define the starting point of the line.
x2 and y2 define the ending point of the line.
stroke defines the color of the line.
stroke-width defines the thickness of the line.

sections.heading: Horizontal Line Example
paragraphs: This example creates a horizontal line.
sections.code:
<svg height="50" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <line x1="0" y1="10" x2="250" y2="10" style="stroke:red; stroke-width:12" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Vertical Line Example
paragraphs: This example creates a vertical line.
sections.code:
<svg height="210" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <line x1="0" y1="0" x2="0" y2="200" style="stroke:red; stroke-width:14" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Polygon
paragraphs: The <polygon> element is used to create a graphic that contains at least three sides.
Polygons are made of straight lines and the shape is automatically closed.

rows: Required. Defines the list of x and y coordinates for the polygon

sections.heading: Polygon With Three Sides
paragraphs: This example creates a triangle using three coordinate points.
sections.code:
<svg height="220" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 150,190 50,190" style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Polygon With Four Sides
paragraphs: This example creates a polygon with four sides.
sections.code:
<svg height="260" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="220,10 300,210 170,250 123,234" style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Polygon With Six Sides
paragraphs: This example creates a polygon with six sides.
sections.code:
<svg height="280" width="360" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="150,15 258,77 258,202 150,265 42,202 42,77" style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Polygon Star
paragraphs: The polygon element can be used to create star shapes.
sections.code:
<svg height="210" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 40,198 190,78 10,78 160,198" style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:5" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Polygon with fill-rule
paragraphs: The fill-rule property specifies how the inside of a shape is filled.
sections.code:
<svg height="210" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 40,198 190,78 10,78 160,198" style="fill:lime;stroke:purple;stroke-width:5;fill-rule:evenodd" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Explanation
paragraphs: The points attribute defines the corners of the polygon.
Each point consists of an x and y coordinate.
The fill-rule property controls how overlapping areas are filled.

sections.heading: SVG Polyline
paragraphs: The <polyline> element is used to create any shape that consists of only straight lines.
A polyline is similar to a polygon, but it does not automatically close the shape.

rows: Required. Defines the list of x and y coordinates for the polyline

sections.heading: Polyline Example
paragraphs: The following example creates a polyline using multiple coordinate points.
sections.code:
<svg height="210" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polyline points="0,0 50,150 100,75 150,50 200,140 250,140"
  style="fill:none;stroke:green;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Code Explanation
paragraphs: The points attribute defines the list of coordinates for the polyline.
Each pair of numbers represents an x and y position.
The fill is set to none so only the outline is visible.
The stroke property defines the color of the line.
The stroke-width property defines the thickness of the line.

sections.heading: Another Polyline Example
paragraphs: This example shows a polyline created using only straight horizontal and vertical lines.
sections.code:
<svg height="180" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polyline points="0,40 40,40 40,80 80,80 80,120 120,120"
  style="fill:yellow;stroke:red;stroke-width:4" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Path
paragraphs: The <path> element is used to define a path.
Paths are used to create simple or complex shapes using straight lines and curves.

rows: Required. Defines the path commands and coordinates

sections.heading: Path Commands
paragraphs: The following commands are used inside the path data:
M = moveto
L = lineto
H = horizontal lineto
V = vertical lineto
C = curveto
S = smooth curveto
Q = quadratic Bézier curve
T = smooth quadratic Bézier curve
A = elliptical arc
Z = close path
Uppercase letters represent absolute positions, lowercase letters represent relative positions.

sections.heading: Simple Path Example
paragraphs: This example creates a triangular path using straight lines.
sections.code:
<svg height="210" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <path d="M150 5 L75 200 L225 200 Z"
  style="fill:none;stroke:green;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Bezier Curve
paragraphs: Bezier curves are used to create smooth curved lines.
A quadratic Bézier curve uses one control point.
The curve is drawn between two points using a control point.

sections.heading: Bezier Curve Example
sections.code:
<svg height="400" width="450" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

<path d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none" />

<circle cx="100" cy="350" r="4" fill="black" />
<circle cx="250" cy="50" r="4" fill="black" />
<circle cx="400" cy="350" r="4" fill="black" />

</svg>

sections.heading: Important Note
paragraphs: SVG paths can be complex and difficult to write manually.
It is recommended to use an SVG editor for complex shapes.
Paths are very powerful and used in icons, animations, and vector graphics.

sections.heading: SVG Text
paragraphs: The <text> element is used to define text in SVG.
It allows positioning, rotation, and styling of text.
Text in SVG is scalable and does not lose quality.

rows: Total width the text should fit into

sections.heading: Simple Text Example
sections.code:
<svg height="30" width="200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <text x="5" y="15" fill="red">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Text With Stroke
sections.code:
<svg height="40" width="200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <text x="5" y="30" fill="none" stroke="red" font-size="35">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Text With Fill and Stroke
sections.code:
<svg height="40" width="200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <text x="5" y="30" fill="pink" stroke="blue" font-size="35">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Rotate Individual Letters
sections.code:
<svg height="40" width="200">
  <text x="5" y="30" fill="red" font-size="35" rotate="30">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Rotate Whole Text
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="200">
  <text x="5" y="30" fill="red" font-size="25" transform="rotate(30 20,40)">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Tspan
paragraphs: The <tspan> element is used to style or position part of a text.
It must be inside a <text> element.
It works similar to the HTML <span> tag.

sections.heading: Tspan Example
sections.code:
<svg height="40" width="250" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <text x="5" y="30" fill="red" font-size="35">
    I Love <tspan fill="none" stroke="green">SVG</tspan>!
  </text>
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG TextPath
paragraphs: The <textPath> element is used to render text along the shape of a path.
It allows text to follow curves or custom shapes defined using SVG paths.

rows: Specifies the path the text follows
Controls how text is stretched or compressed
Defines how glyphs are rendered along the path
Defines where the text begins along the path
Specifies the total length of the text

sections.heading: Text Along a Path
paragraphs: The <textPath> element is placed inside a <text> element.
The text follows the shape of the referenced path.
sections.code:
<svg height="200" width="350" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <path id="lineAC" d="M 30 180 q 150 -250 300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="2" fill="none" />
  <text style="fill:red;font-size:25px;">
    <textPath href="#lineAC" startOffset="80">
      I love SVG! I love SVG!
    </textPath>
  </text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Text Along a Path Using textLength
paragraphs: The textLength attribute controls how much of the path the text should occupy.
This allows stretching or compressing the text along the path.
sections.code:
<svg height="200" width="350" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <path id="lineAC" d="M 30 180 q 150 -250 300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="2" fill="none" />
  <text style="fill:red;font-size:25px;">
    <textPath href="#lineAC" textLength="100%" startOffset="20">
      I love SVG! I love SVG!
    </textPath>
  </text>
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Links
paragraphs: The <a> element is used to create links in SVG.
The <a> element can be used with both text and graphics.

rows: Forces the browser to download the file
Specifies the language of the linked document
Controls what referrer information is sent
Defines the relationship between the current and target document
Specifies where to open the link
Specifies the MIME type of the linked resource

sections.heading: Text as a Hyperlink
paragraphs: SVG text can be wrapped inside an <a> element to create a clickable link.
The link behaves like a normal HTML hyperlink.

sections.heading: Graphic as a Hyperlink
paragraphs: SVG graphics such as circles, rectangles, or images can also be clickable.
The <a> element wraps the graphical object.

sections.heading: SVG Image
paragraphs: The <image> element is used to insert an image into an SVG.
SVG supports image formats like JPEG, PNG, and SVG.
The <image> element allows positioning and resizing of images inside SVG.

rows: Required. The width of the image
Required. The height of the image
Required. The URL of the image

sections.heading: Insert an Image
paragraphs: You can insert an image inside SVG using the <image> element.
The image file can be a JPG, PNG, or another SVG.
sections.code:
<svg height="200" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <image height="200" width="300" href="pulpitrock.jpg" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Add Image with Graphics
paragraphs: SVG images can be combined with other shapes like circles and text.
This example shows an image placed over a circle with text.
sections.code:
<svg height="250" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <circle r="105" cx="150" cy="120" fill="lightblue" />
  <image x="0" y="60" width="300" height="100" href="pulpitrock.jpg" />
  <text x="84" y="180" fill="black">Pulpit Rock, Norway</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Marker
paragraphs: The <marker> element is used to create markers for the start, middle, or end of SVG shapes.
Markers can be applied to lines, paths, polylines, and polygons.
Markers are defined inside the <defs> element.

rows: X coordinate where the marker connects
Y coordinate where the marker connects

sections.heading: Line with Start and End Marker
paragraphs: Markers can be added to the start and end of a line.
Markers are referenced using marker-start and marker-end.
sections.code:
<svg height="250" width="350" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <marker id="circle" markerWidth="8" markerHeight="8" refX="5" refY="5">
      <circle cx="5" cy="5" r="3" fill="black" />
    </marker>
    <marker id="arrow" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="5" refY="5" orient="auto">
      <path d="M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z" fill="black" />
    </marker>
  </defs>

  <line x1="10" y1="10" x2="300" y2="200" stroke="red" stroke-width="3"
        marker-start="url(#circle)" marker-end="url(#arrow)" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Using Mid Marker
paragraphs: Markers can also be placed in the middle of a path using marker-mid.
The same marker can be reused multiple times.
sections.code:
<svg height="250" width="350" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <marker id="circle" markerWidth="8" markerHeight="8" refX="5" refY="5">
      <circle cx="5" cy="5" r="2" fill="black" />
    </marker>
    <marker id="arrow" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="5" refY="5" orient="auto">
      <path d="M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z" fill="black" />
    </marker>
  </defs>

  <polyline points="15,40 15,170 200,170"
            stroke="red"
            stroke-width="3"
            fill="none"
            marker-start="url(#circle)"
            marker-mid="url(#circle)"
            marker-end="url(#arrow)" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Fill Attributes
paragraphs: The fill attribute defines the color inside an SVG shape.
SVG provides three fill-related attributes: fill, fill-opacity, and fill-rule.

sections.heading: Fill Attribute
paragraphs: The fill attribute sets the color of the inside of an SVG element.
It can be used with elements such as circle, rect, polygon, polyline, path, text, and others.
The value of fill can be a color name, RGB value, or hex value.
sections.code:
<svg width="600" height="220" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="50,10 0,190 100,190" fill="lime" />
  <rect width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="blue" />
  <circle r="45" cx="350" cy="100" fill="red" />
  <text x="420" y="100" fill="red">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Fill Opacity
paragraphs: The fill-opacity attribute controls the transparency of the fill color.
Its value ranges from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).
It can also be expressed in percentages.
sections.code:
<svg width="600" height="220" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="50,10 0,190 100,190" fill="lime" fill-opacity="0.5" />
  <rect width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="blue" fill-opacity="50%" />
  <circle r="45" cx="350" cy="100" fill="red" fill-opacity="0.6" />
  <text x="420" y="100" fill="red" fill-opacity="70%">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Fill Rule
paragraphs: The fill-rule attribute determines how the inside of a shape is calculated.
It is mainly used with complex shapes such as polygons and paths.
The two possible values are: nonzero and evenodd.

sections.heading: Fill Rule Example (evenodd)
sections.code:
<svg height="210" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 40,198 190,78 10,78 160,198" fill="lime" fill-rule="evenodd" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Fill Rule Example (nonzero)
sections.code:
<svg height="210" width="500" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="100,10 40,198 190,78 10,78 160,198" fill="lime" fill-rule="nonzero" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Stroke Attribute
paragraphs: The stroke attribute defines the color of the outline of an SVG shape.
It can be used with elements such as circle, rect, path, polygon, polyline, and text.
sections.code:
<svg width="600" height="220" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <circle r="45" cx="350" cy="100" fill="pink" stroke="blue" />
  <text x="420" y="100" fill="red" stroke="blue">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Stroke Example (Multiple Lines)
paragraphs: The stroke attribute can be used to define different stroke colors for multiple lines.
sections.code:
<svg height="80" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none">
    <path stroke="red" d="M5 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke="green" d="M5 40 l215 0" />
    <path stroke="blue" d="M5 60 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG stroke-width Attribute
paragraphs: The stroke-width attribute defines the thickness of the outline.
It works with shapes such as circle, rectangle, polygon, text, and path.
sections.code:
<svg width="600" height="220" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="55,10 10,190 110,190" fill="lime" stroke="red" stroke-width="4" />
  <rect width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="yellow" stroke="red" stroke-width="4" />
  <circle r="45" cx="350" cy="100" fill="pink" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" />
  <text x="420" y="100" fill="red" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Stroke Width Example (Lines)
sections.code:
<svg height="80" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none" stroke="red">
    <path stroke-width="2" d="M5 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-width="4" d="M5 40 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-width="6" d="M5 60 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG stroke-opacity Attribute
paragraphs: The stroke-opacity attribute controls the transparency of the stroke.
Its value ranges from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).
sections.code:
<svg width="600" height="220" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <polygon points="55,10 10,190 110,190" fill="lime" stroke="red" stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.4" />
  <rect width="150" height="100" x="120" y="50" fill="yellow" stroke="red" stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.4" />
  <circle r="45" cx="350" cy="100" fill="pink" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.4" />
  <text x="420" y="100" fill="red" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.4">I love SVG!</text>
</svg>

sections.heading: Stroke Opacity Example (Lines)
sections.code:
<svg height="80" width="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <g fill="none" stroke="red">
    <path stroke-width="2" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 20 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-width="4" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 40 l215 0" />
    <path stroke-width="6" stroke-opacity="0.4" d="M5 60 l215 0" />
  </g>
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Filters Introduction
paragraphs: SVG filters are used to add special visual effects to SVG graphics.
All SVG filters are defined inside a <defs> element.
The <filter> element defines the filter and must have an id attribute.
SVG elements reference the filter using the filter attribute.

sections.heading: Basic SVG Filter Example
paragraphs: This example uses the feGaussianBlur filter to blur an SVG rectangle.
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f1" x="0" y="0">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceGraphic" stdDeviation="15" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" fill="red" filter="url(#f1)" />
</svg>

sections.heading: SVG Filter Elements
paragraphs: SVG provides many built-in filter effects that can be combined together.

rows: Combines two images using a mathematical operation
Applies convolution effects like blur or sharpen
Fills an area with a color

sections.heading: Important Notes
paragraphs: SVG filters must be defined inside the <defs> element.
Multiple filter effects can be combined in one filter.
Filters can be applied to shapes, text, and images.
Filters may impact performance when overused.

sections.heading: SVG <feGaussianBlur>
paragraphs: The <feGaussianBlur> filter is used to create blur effects in SVG graphics.
It applies a Gaussian blur to the input image.
The blur effect is defined inside a <filter> element.

sections.heading: Basic Blur Example
paragraphs: This example applies a blur effect to a rectangle using feGaussianBlur.
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f1" x="0" y="0">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceGraphic" stdDeviation="15" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" fill="yellow" filter="url(#f1)" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Code Explanation
points: The id attribute identifies the filter.
The <feGaussianBlur> element applies the blur effect.
The in="SourceGraphic" attribute means the effect is applied to the original element.
The stdDeviation attribute controls the blur strength.
The filter attribute links the SVG element to the filter.

sections.heading: Higher Blur Example
paragraphs: Increasing the stdDeviation value increases the blur intensity.
sections.code:
<svg height="100" width="100" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f2" x="0" y="0">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceGraphic" stdDeviation="55" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" fill="yellow" filter="url(#f2)" />
</svg>

sections.heading: Important Notes
points: Higher stdDeviation values produce more blur.
Blur filters must be defined inside <defs>.
The filter is applied using the filter attribute.
SVG blur effects can be combined with other filters.

svg-shadow1.title: SVG Drop Shadow 1
svg-shadow1.description: The <feDropShadow> filter is used to create a drop shadow effect on SVG elements.

example.code:
<svg height="110" width="110" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f1">
      <feDropShadow dx="12" dy="14" stdDeviation="1" flood-opacity="0.7" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" fill="yellow" filter="url(#f1)" />
</svg>

attributes.name: id
attributes.description: Defines a unique name for the filter

attributes.name: dx
attributes.description: Defines the horizontal offset of the drop shadow

attributes.name: dy
attributes.description: Defines the vertical offset of the drop shadow

attributes.name: stdDeviation
attributes.description: Defines the blur amount of the shadow

attributes.name: flood-opacity
attributes.description: Defines the opacity of the shadow (0 to 1)

attributes.name: filter
attributes.description: Applies the filter to the SVG element using the filter ID

notes: The <filter> element must be inside <defs>
The filter is applied using the filter attribute
Drop shadow effects work on SVG shapes like rect, circle, text, etc.

svg-shadow2.title: SVG Drop Shadow 2
svg-shadow2.description: The <feOffset> filter is used to create a drop shadow by shifting an element in the X and Y directions. It is often combined with <feBlend>, <feGaussianBlur>, and <feColorMatrix> for advanced shadow effects.

sections.title: Basic Drop Shadow using feOffset and feBlend
sections.description: Offsets the original graphic and blends it with the original element.

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f1" width="120" height="120">
      <feOffset in="SourceGraphic" dx="20" dy="20" />
      <feBlend in="SourceGraphic" in2="offOut" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" stroke="green" stroke-width="3" fill="yellow" filter="url(#f1)" />
</svg>

notes: dx defines horizontal offset
dy defines vertical offset
feBlend merges original and offset graphics

sections.title: Blurred Shadow using feGaussianBlur
sections.description: Adds blur to the shadow to create a smooth shadow effect.

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f2" width="120" height="120">
      <feOffset in="SourceGraphic" dx="20" dy="20" />
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="10" />
      <feBlend in="SourceGraphic" in2="blurOut" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" stroke="green" stroke-width="3" fill="yellow" filter="url(#f2)" />
</svg>

notes: stdDeviation controls blur intensity
Higher values create softer shadows

sections.title: Black Shadow using SourceAlpha
sections.description: Creates a solid black shadow using alpha channel instead of full color.

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f3" width="120" height="120">
      <feOffset in="SourceAlpha" dx="20" dy="20" />
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="10" />
      <feBlend in="SourceGraphic" in2="blurOut" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" stroke="green" stroke-width="3" fill="yellow" filter="url(#f3)" />
</svg>

notes: SourceAlpha uses transparency instead of colors
Creates more realistic shadows

sections.title: Colored Shadow using feColorMatrix
sections.description: Applies a color transformation matrix to control shadow color.

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <filter id="f4" width="120" height="120">
      <feOffset in="SourceGraphic" dx="20" dy="20" />
      <feColorMatrix type="matrix" values="0.2 0 0 0 0  0 0.2 0 0 0  0 0 0.2 0 0  0 0 0 1 0" />
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="10" />
      <feBlend in="SourceGraphic" in2="blurOut" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  <rect width="90" height="90" stroke="green" stroke-width="3" fill="yellow" filter="url(#f4)" />
</svg>

notes: feColorMatrix allows color manipulation
Matrix values define RGB and alpha behavior
Useful for colored or tinted shadows

svg-linear-gradient.title: SVG Linear Gradient
svg-linear-gradient.description: A gradient is a smooth transition between two or more colors. SVG supports linear gradients using the <linearGradient> element.

sections.title: Basic Horizontal Linear Gradient

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="grad1" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="yellow" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="red" />
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad1)" />
</svg>

notes: x1 and x2 define horizontal direction
Colors are defined using <stop>
fill links the shape to the gradient

sections.title: Multi-Color Horizontal Gradient
sections.description: A gradient with more than two colors.

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="grad2" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="yellow" />
      <stop offset="50%" stop-color="green" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="red" />
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad2)" />
</svg>

<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="grad3" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="yellow" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="red" />
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad3)" />
</svg>

sections.title: Gradient with Text
sections.description: Applies a gradient to a shape with text overlay.

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="grad4" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="yellow" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="red" />
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad4)" />
  <text x="50" y="86" font-size="45" fill="white" font-family="Verdana">SVG</text>
</svg>

sections.title: Angular Linear Gradient
sections.description: Creates a diagonal gradient by changing both x and y coordinates.

example.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="grad5" x1="0%" y1="100%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="yellow" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="red" />
    </linearGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad5)" />
</svg>

svg-radial-gradient.title: SVG Radial Gradient
svg-radial-gradient.description: Radial gradients create circular color transitions using the <radialGradient> element in SVG.

overview.definition: A radial gradient transitions colors outward from a center point.

examples.title: Radial Gradient 1
examples.description: Simple red to blue radial gradient
examples.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="grad1" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%" fx="50%" fy="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="red" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="blue" />
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad1)" />
</svg>

examples.title: Radial Gradient 2
examples.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="grad2" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="red" />
      <stop offset="50%" stop-color="green" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="blue" />
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad2)" />
</svg>

examples.title: Radial Gradient with Offset Center
examples.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="grad3" cx="25%" cy="25%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="red" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="blue" />
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad3)" />
</svg>

examples.title: Spread Method: Reflect
examples.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="grad4" cx="25%" cy="25%" spreadMethod="reflect">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="red" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="blue" />
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad4)" />
</svg>

examples.title: Spread Method: Repeat
examples.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="grad5" cx="25%" cy="25%" spreadMethod="repeat">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="red" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="blue" />
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad5)" />
</svg>

examples.title: Radial Gradient with Opacity
examples.code:
<svg height="150" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="grad6" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="red" stop-opacity="0" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="blue" stop-opacity="1" />
    </radialGradient>
  </defs>
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="70" rx="85" ry="55" fill="url(#grad6)" />
</svg>

svg-patterns.title: SVG Patterns
svg-patterns.description: SVG patterns are used to fill shapes with repeating graphics using the <pattern> element.

overview.definition: A pattern creates a repeated graphic fill using x and y coordinates.

basic_example.title: Simple Pattern
basic_example.code:
<svg width="400" height="110" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <pattern id="patt1" x="0" y="0" width="20" height="20" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
      <circle cx="10" cy="10" r="10" fill="red" />
    </pattern>
  </defs>
  <rect width="200" height="100" stroke="black" fill="url(#patt1)" />
</svg>

pattern_with_gradient.title: Pattern with Gradient
pattern_with_gradient.description: Pattern combining shapes and linear gradient
pattern_with_gradient.code:
<svg width="200" height="200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="grad1">
      <stop offset="0%" stop-color="white" />
      <stop offset="100%" stop-color="red" />
    </linearGradient>
    <pattern id="patt2" x="0" y="0" width="0.25" height="0.25">
      <rect x="0" y="0" width="50" height="50" fill="lightblue" />
      <circle cx="25" cy="25" r="20" fill="url(#grad1)" fill-opacity="0.8" />
    </pattern>
  </defs>
  <rect width="200" height="200" fill="url(#patt2)" />
</svg>

attributes.id: Defines a unique name for the pattern
attributes.fill: Applies the pattern to a shape

key_points: Can include shapes, gradients, and images
Commonly used for backgrounds and textures

svg-transform.title: SVG Transformations
svg-transform.description: SVG elements can be manipulated using transform functions that change position, size, rotation, and skewing.

translate.description: Moves an element along the X and Y axis.

scale.description: Scales an element in X and Y direction.

rotate.description: Rotates an element by a specified angle.

skewX.description: Skews an element along the X-axis.

skewY.description: Skews an element along the Y-axis.

notes: The transform attribute can be applied to any SVG element.
Transformations affect both the element and its children.
Multiple transform functions can be combined.

svg-clip-mask.title: SVG Clip / Mask
svg-clip-mask.description: SVG elements can be clipped or masked to control which parts are visible using clip paths or masks.

clipping.description: Clipping removes parts of an element that fall outside a defined shape using <clipPath>.
clipping.behavior: Only the area inside the clipping path is visible.

example.result: Only the clipped area of the circle is visible

masking.description: Masking controls visibility using opacity values.
masking.behavior: White areas are visible, black areas are hidden, gray values create transparency.

clipPath.usage: Used to clip parts of an SVG element
rules: Uses shapes like rect, circle, path

example.effect: Only top half of the circle is visible

mask.usage: Used to control opacity of SVG elements

mask_opacity.description: Mask opacity is controlled using colors

gradient_masking.description: Gradients can be used inside masks to create fading effects
gradient_masking.example: Linear gradient used as mask fill

important_notes: clipPath hides areas outside the defined shape
mask uses color brightness to control visibility
Masks allow transparency, clip paths do not

svg-animation.title: SVG Animation
svg-animation.description: SVG allows animation of elements using built-in animation tags without JavaScript.

set.description: Sets the value of an attribute for a specific duration.

animate.description: Animates an attribute value over time.

animateTransform.description: Animates transformations like rotate, scale, or translate.

animateMotion.description: Moves elements along a defined path.
animateMotion.example: Moving text and shapes along a curved path

important_notes: Animations are defined inside SVG elements

svg-scripting.title: SVG Scripting
svg-scripting.description: SVG can be combined with JavaScript to dynamically modify and animate SVG elements.

svg_with_javascript.description: JavaScript can be used to manipulate SVG elements using DOM methods.

change_css.description: CSS properties of SVG elements can be changed using JavaScript.

change_attributes_and_css.description: SVG attributes and styles can be changed together.

svg_animation_with_script.description: JavaScript can animate SVG elements using timers.

notes: SVG elements can be controlled like HTML DOM elements
JavaScript allows interactivity
Animations can be manual or automatic
Works in all modern browsers

svg-examples.title: SVG Examples
svg-examples.description: Collection of SVG examples demonstrating shapes, text, transformations, animation, filters, gradients, masking, and scripting.

examples: Text along a path using textLength
Line with start and end markers
Pattern with rectangles and gradient circles

svg-quiz.title: SVG Quiz
svg-quiz.description: Test your SVG knowledge with an interactive quiz provided by W3Schools.

details.purpose: Evaluate your understanding of SVG concepts and features
details.note: This quiz is not official and is intended for practice and self-assessment

actions.suggested_preparation: Read the SVG Tutorial before attempting the quiz

svg-reference.title: SVG Reference
svg-reference.description: Complete reference of SVG elements and their attributes.

elements.name: a
elements.description: Creates a hyperlink around an element

elements.name: animate
elements.description: Animates an attribute of an element over time

elements.name: animateMotion
elements.description: Moves an element along a motion path

elements.name: animateTransform
elements.description: Animates transformations such as scale, rotate, translate

elements.name: desc
elements.description: Provides a text description for accessibility

elements.name: feBlend
elements.description: Blends two images using blending modes

elements.name: feComponentTransfer
elements.description: Adjusts brightness and contrast of pixels

elements.name: feComposite
elements.description: Combines two images using compositing operations

elements.name: feConvolveMatrix
elements.description: Applies convolution filters such as blur or sharpen

elements.name: feFlood
elements.description: Fills an area with a solid color
